com.qozix.tileview

Class TileView

  • java.lang.Object
    • ViewGroup
      • com.qozix.tileview.widgets.ZoomPanLayout
        • com.qozix.tileview.TileView
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DetailLevelManager.DetailLevelChangeListener, TileCanvasViewGroup.TileRenderListener, TouchUpGestureDetector.OnTouchUpListener, ZoomPanLayout.ZoomPanListener

    public class TileView
extends ZoomPanLayout
implements ZoomPanLayout.ZoomPanListener, TileCanvasViewGroup.TileRenderListener, DetailLevelManager.DetailLevelChangeListener
    The TileView widget is a subclass of ViewGroup that supports: 1. Memory-managed tiled images with multiple levels of detail. 2. Panning by drag and fling. 3. Zooming by pinch and double-tap. 4. Markers and info windows. 5. Arbitrary coordinate systems. 6. Tappable hot spots. 7. Path drawing. A minimal implementation might look like this: 
    TileView tileView = new TileView( this );
 tileView.setSize( 3000, 5000 );
 tileView.addDetailLevel( 1.0f, "path/to/tiles/%d-%d.jpg" );
    A more advanced implementation might look like: 
    TileView tileView = new TileView( this );
 tileView.setSize( 3000, 5000 );
 tileView.defineBounds( 42.379676, -71.094919, 42.346550, -71.040280 );
 tileView.addDetailLevel( 1.000f, "path/to/tiles/1000/%d-%d.jpg", 256, 256 );
 tileView.addDetailLevel( 0.500f, "path/to/tiles/500/%d-%d.jpg", 256, 256 );
 tileView.addDetailLevel( 0.250f, "path/to/tiles/250/%d-%d.jpg", 256, 256 );
 tileView.addDetailLevel( 0.125f, "path/to/tiles/125/%d-%d.jpg", 128, 128 );
 tileView.addMarker( someView, 42.35848, -71.063736, null, null );
 tileView.addMarker( anotherView, 42.3665, -71.05224, -1.0f, -0.5f );
 tileView.setMarkerTapListener( someMarkerTapListenerImplementation );

      • getScalingLayout

        public ScalingLayout getScalingLayout()
        Returns the ScalingLayout instance used by the TileView to allow insertion of arbitrary Views and ViewGroups that will scale visually with the TileView.
        Returns:
        The ScalingLayout instance.

      • addScalingViewGroup

        public void addScalingViewGroup(ViewGroup viewGroup)
        Add a ViewGroup to the TileView at a z-index above tiles and paths but beneath markers and callouts. The ViewGroup will be laid out to the full dimensions of the largest detail level, and will scale with the TileView. Note that only the drawing surface of the view is scaled, other operations that depend on dimensions are not (e.g., hit areas, invalidation tests).
        Parameters:
        viewGroup - The ViewGroup to be added to the TileView, that will scale visually.

      • requestRender

        public void requestRender()
        Request that the current tile set is re-examined and re-drawn. The request is added to a queue and is not guaranteed to be processed at any particular time, and will never be handled immediately.

      • requestThrottledRender

        public void requestThrottledRender()
        While all render operation requests are queued and batched, this method provides an additional throttle layer, so that any subsequent invocations cancel and pending invocations. This is useful when requesting in a stream fashion, either in a loop or in response to a progressive action like an animation or touch move.

      • requestSafeRender

        protected void requestSafeRender()
        If flinging, defer render, otherwise request now. If a render operation starts at the beginning of a fling, a stutter can occur.

      • cancelRender

        public void cancelRender()
        Notify the TileView that it may stop rendering tiles. The rendering thread will be sent an interrupt request, but no guarantee is provided when the request will be responded to.

      • suppressRender

        public void suppressRender()
        Notify the TileView that it should continue to render any pending tiles, but should not accept new render tasks.

      • setBitmapProvider

        public void setBitmapProvider(BitmapProvider bitmapProvider)
        Sets a custom class to perform the getBitmap operation when tile bitmaps are requested for tile images only. By default, a BitmapDecoder implementation is provided that renders bitmaps from the context's Assets, but alternative implementations could be used that fetch images via HTTP, or from the SD card, or resources, SVG, etc.
        Parameters:
        bitmapProvider - A class instance that implements BitmapProvider, and must define a getBitmap method, which accepts a String file name and a Context object, and returns a Bitmap

      • setTransitionsEnabled

        public void setTransitionsEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Defines whether tile bitmaps should be rendered using an AlphaAnimation
        Parameters:
        enabled - True if the TileView should render tiles with fade transitions

      • setSize

        public void setSize(int width,
           int height)
        Defines the total size, in pixels, of the tile set at 100% scale. The TileView wills pan within it's layout dimensions, with the content (scrollable) size defined by this method.
        Overrides:
        setSize in class ZoomPanLayout
        Parameters:
        width - Total width of the tiled set.
        height - Total height of the tiled set.

      • addDetailLevel

        public void addDetailLevel(float detailScale,
                  java.lang.Object data)
        Register a tile set to be used for a particular detail level. Each tile set to be used must be registered using this method, and at least one tile set must be registered for the TileView to render any tiles.
        Parameters:
        detailScale - Scale at which the TileView should use the tiles in this set.
        data - An arbitrary object of any type that is passed to the BitmapProvider for each tile on this level.

      • addDetailLevel

        public void addDetailLevel(float detailScale,
                  java.lang.Object data,
                  int tileWidth,
                  int tileHeight)
        Register a tile set to be used for a particular detail level. Each tile set to be used must be registered using this method, and at least one tile set must be registered for the TileView to render any tiles.
        Parameters:
        detailScale - Scale at which the TileView should use the tiles in this set.
        data - An arbitrary object of any type that is passed to the (Adapter|Decoder) for each tile on this level.
        tileWidth - Size of each tiled column.
        tileHeight - Size of each tiled row.

      • setViewportPadding

        public void setViewportPadding(int padding)
        Pads the viewport by the number of pixels passed. e.g., setViewportPadding( 100 ) instructs the TileView to interpret it's actual viewport offset by 100 pixels in each direction (top, left, right, bottom), so more tiles will qualify for "visible" status when intersections are calculated.
        Parameters:
        padding - The number of pixels to pad the viewport by

      • defineBounds

        public void defineBounds(double left,
                double top,
                double right,
                double bottom)
        Register a set of offset points to use when calculating position within the TileView. Any type of coordinate system can be used (any type of lat/lng, percentile-based, etc), and all positioned are calculated relatively. If relative bounds are defined, position parameters received by TileView methods will be translated to the the appropriate pixel value. To remove this process, use undefineBounds.
        Parameters:
        left - The left edge of the rectangle used when calculating position.
        top - The top edge of the rectangle used when calculating position.
        right - The right edge of the rectangle used when calculating position.
        bottom - The bottom edge of the rectangle used when calculating position.

      • undefineBounds

        public void undefineBounds()
        Unregisters arbitrary bounds and coordinate system. After invoking this method, TileView methods that receive position method parameters will use pixel values, relative to the TileView's registered size (at 1.0f scale).

      • scrollTo

        public void scrollTo(double x,
            double y)
        Scrolls (instantly) the TileView to the x and y positions provided. The is an overload of scrollTo( int x, int y ) that accepts doubles; if the TileView has relative bounds defined, those relative doubles will be converted to absolute pixel positions.
        Parameters:
        x - The relative x position to move to.
        y - The relative y position to move to.

      • scrollToAndCenter

        public void scrollToAndCenter(double x,
                     double y)
        Scrolls (instantly) the TileView to the x and y positions provided, then centers the viewport to the position.
        Parameters:
        x - The relative x position to move to.
        y - The relative y position to move to.

      • slideTo

        public void slideTo(double x,
           double y)
        Scrolls (with animation) the TileView to the relative x and y positions provided.
        Parameters:
        x - The relative x position to move to.
        y - The relative y position to move to.

      • slideToAndCenter

        public void slideToAndCenter(double x,
                    double y)
        Scrolls (with animation) the TileView to the x and y positions provided, then centers the viewport to the position.
        Parameters:
        x - The relative x position to move to.
        y - The relative y position to move to.

      • slideToAndCenterWithScale

        public void slideToAndCenterWithScale(double x,
                             double y,
                             float scale)
        Scrolls and scales (with animation) the TileView to the specified x, y and scale provided. The TileView will be centered to the coordinates passed.
        Parameters:
        x - The relative x position to move to.
        y - The relative y position to move to.
        scale - The scale the TileView should be at when the animation is complete.

      • setMarkerAnchorPoints

        public void setMarkerAnchorPoints(java.lang.Float anchorX,
                         java.lang.Float anchorY)
        Markers added to this TileView will have anchor logic applied on the values provided here. E.g., setMarkerAnchorPoints(-0.5f, -1.0f) will have markers centered horizontally, and aligned along the bottom edge to the y value supplied. Anchor values assigned to individual markers will override these default values.
        Parameters:
        anchorX - The x-axis position of a marker will be offset by a number equal to the width of the marker multiplied by this value.
        anchorY - The y-axis position of a marker will be offset by a number equal to the height of the marker multiplied by this value.

      • addMarker

        public View addMarker(View view,
             double x,
             double y,
             java.lang.Float anchorX,
             java.lang.Float anchorY)
        Add a marker to the the TileView. The marker can be any View. No LayoutParams are required; the View will be laid out using WRAP_CONTENT for both width and height, and positioned based on the parameters.
        Parameters:
        view - View instance to be added to the TileView.
        x - Relative x position the View instance should be positioned at.
        y - Relative y position the View instance should be positioned at.
        anchorX - The x-axis position of a marker will be offset by a number equal to the width of the marker multiplied by this value.
        anchorY - The y-axis position of a marker will be offset by a number equal to the height of the marker multiplied by this value.
        Returns:
        The View instance added to the TileView.

      • removeMarker

        public void removeMarker(View view)
        Removes a marker View from the TileView's view tree.
        Parameters:
        view - The marker View to be removed.

      • moveMarker

        public void moveMarker(View view,
              double x,
              double y)
        Moves an existing marker to another position.
        Parameters:
        view - The marker View to be repositioned.
        x - Relative x position the View instance should be positioned at.
        y - Relative y position the View instance should be positioned at.

      • moveToMarker

        public void moveToMarker(View view,
                boolean shouldAnimate)
        Scroll the TileView so that the View passed is centered in the viewport.
        Parameters:
        view - The View marker that the TileView should center on.
        shouldAnimate - True if the movement should use a transition effect.

      • setMarkerTapListener

        public void setMarkerTapListener(MarkerLayout.MarkerTapListener markerTapListener)
        Register a MarkerTapListener for the TileView instance (rather than on a single marker view). Unlike standard touch events attached to marker View's (e.g., View.OnClickListener), MarkerTapListener.onMarkerTapEvent does not consume the touch event, so will not interfere with scrolling.
        Parameters:
        markerTapListener - Listener to be added to the TileView's list of MarkerTapListener.

      • addCallout

        public View addCallout(View view,
              double x,
              double y,
              java.lang.Float anchorX,
              java.lang.Float anchorY)
        Add a callout to the the TileView. The callout can be any View. No LayoutParams are required; the View will be laid out using WRAP_CONTENT for both width and height, and positioned according to the x and y values supplied. Callout views will always be positioned at the top of the view tree (at the highest z-index), and will always be removed during any touch event that is not consumed by the callout View.
        Parameters:
        view - View instance to be added to the TileView.
        x - Relative x position the View instance should be positioned at.
        y - Relative y position the View instance should be positioned at.
        anchorX - The x-axis position of a callout view will be offset by a number equal to the width of the callout view multiplied by this value.
        anchorY - The y-axis position of a callout view will be offset by a number equal to the height of the callout view multiplied by this value.
        Returns:
        The View instance added to the TileView.

      • removeCallout

        public void removeCallout(View view)
        Removes a callout View from the TileView.
        Parameters:
        view - The callout View to be removed.

      • addHotSpot

        public HotSpot addHotSpot(HotSpot hotSpot)
        Register a HotSpot that should fire a listener when a touch event occurs that intersects the Region defined by the HotSpot. The HotSpot virtually moves and scales with the TileView.
        Parameters:
        hotSpot - The hotspot that is tested against touch events that occur on the TileView.
        Returns:
        The HotSpot instance added.

      • addHotSpot

        public HotSpot addHotSpot(java.util.List<double[]> positions,
                 HotSpot.HotSpotTapListener listener)
        Register a HotSpot that should fire a listener when a touch event occurs that intersects the Region defined by the HotSpot. The HotSpot virtually moves and scales with the TileView.
        Parameters:
        positions - (List) List of paired doubles that represents the region.
        Returns:
        HotSpot the hotspot created with this method.

      • removeHotSpot

        public void removeHotSpot(HotSpot hotSpot)
        Remove a HotSpot registered with addHotSpot.
        Parameters:
        hotSpot - The HotSpot instance to remove.

      • setHotSpotTapListener

        public void setHotSpotTapListener(HotSpot.HotSpotTapListener hotSpotTapListener)
        Register a HotSpotTapListener with the TileView. This listener will fire if any registered HotSpot's region intersects a Tap event.
        Parameters:
        hotSpotTapListener - The listener to be added.

      • drawPath

        public CompositePathView.DrawablePath drawPath(CompositePathView.DrawablePath drawablePath)
        Register a DrawablePath that will be drawn on a layer above the tiles, but below markers. The Path will be scaled with the TileView, but will always be as wide as the stroke set for the Paint instance associated with the DrawablePath.
        Parameters:
        drawablePath - DrawablePath instance to be drawn by the TileView.
        Returns:
        The DrawablePath instance passed to the TileView.

      • drawPath

        public CompositePathView.DrawablePath drawPath(java.util.List<double[]> positions,
                                      Paint paint)
        Register a Path and Paint that will be drawn on a layer above the tiles, but below markers. The Path will be scaled with the TileView, but will always be as wide as the stroke set for the Paint.
        Parameters:
        positions - List of doubles that represent the points of the Path.
        paint - The Paint instance that defines the style of the drawn path.
        Returns:
        The DrawablePath instance passed to the TileView.

      • removePath

        public void removePath(CompositePathView.DrawablePath drawablePath)
        Removes a DrawablePath from the TileView's registry. This path will no longer be drawn by the TileView.
        Parameters:
        drawablePath - The DrawablePath instance to be removed.

      • getDefaultPathPaint

        public Paint getDefaultPathPaint()
        Returns the Paint instance used by the CompositePathView by default. This can be modified for future Path paint operations.
        Returns:
        The Paint instance used by default.

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Recycles bitmap image files, prevents path drawing, and clears pending Handler messages, appropriate for Activity.onPause.

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Clear tile image files and remove all views, appropriate for Activity.onDestroy. After invoking this method, the TileView instance should be removed from any view trees, and references to it should be set to null.

      • resume

        public void resume()
        Restore visible state (generally after a call to pause). Appropriate for Activity.onResume.

        protected void onLayout(boolean changed,
            int l,
            int t,
            int r,
            int b)
        Overrides:
        onLayout in class ZoomPanLayout

        protected void updateViewport()

                   int t,
                   int oldl,
